div.p: The first part Of the true and honorable historie, of the life of Sir John Old-castle, the good Lord Cobham. As it hath been lately acted by the right honorable the Earle of Notingham Lord high Admirall of England his seruants.
LONDON Printed by V.S. for Thomas Pauier, and are to be solde at his shop at the signe of the Catte and Parrots neere the Exchange. 1600.

sp.speaker: The Prologue.
sp.l: THe doubtful Tule (Gentlemen) prefixed
Upon the Argument we have in hand,
May breed suspense, and wrongfully disturb
The peaceful quiet of your settled thoughts:
To stop which scruple, let this brief suffice.
It is no pampered glutton we present,
Nor aged Councillor to youthful sin,
But one, whose virtue shone above the rest,
A valiant Martyr, and a virtuous peer,
In whose true faith and loyalty expressed
Unto his sovereign, and his countries weal:
We strive to pay that tribute of our Love,
Your favours merit, let fair Truth be graced,
Since forged invention former time defaced.

div.stage: In the fight, enter the Sheriffe and two of his men.

sp.speaker: Sheriffe.
sp.l: MY Lords, I charge ye in his Highness name,
To keep the peace, you, and your followers.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Good M. Sheriff, look unto yourself.

sp.speaker: Pow.
sp.p: Do so, for we have other business.

sp.speaker: Sher.
sp.l: Will ye disturb the Judges, and the Assize?
Hear the Kings proclamation ye were best.

sp.speaker: Pow.
sp.p: Hold then, let us hear it.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: But be brief, ye were best.

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.p: O yes.

sp.speaker: Dauy
sp.p: Cossone, make shorter O, or shall mar your Yes.

sp.speaker: Bay.
sp.p: O yes.

sp.speaker: Owen
sp.p: What, has her nothing to say but O yes?

sp.speaker: Bay.
sp.p: O yes.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.l: O nay, pye Cosse plut down with her, down with her,
A Pawesse a Pawesse.

sp.speaker: Gough
sp.p: A Herbert a Herbert, and down with Powesse.

sp.speaker: Sher.
sp.p: Hold, in the Kings name, hold.

sp.speaker: Owen
sp.p: Down in the knaves name, down.

stage.hi: In this fight, the Bailiffe is knocked downe, and the Sheriffe and the other runne away.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Powesse, I think thy Welsh and thou do smart.

sp.speaker: Pow.
sp.p: Herbert, I think my sword came near thy heart.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Thy hearts best blood shall pay the loss of mine.

sp.speaker: Gough
sp.p: A Herbert a Herbert.

sp.speaker: Dauy
sp.p: A Pawesse a Pawesse.

div.stage: As they are lifting their weapons, enter the Maior of Hereford, and his Officers and Townes men with clubbes.

sp.speaker: Maior
sp.l: My Lords, as you are liege men to the Crown,
True noblemen, and subjects to the King,
Attend his Highness proclamation,
Commanded by the Judges of Assize,
For keeping peace at this assembly.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Good M. Mayor of Hereford be brief.

sp.speaker: Mai.
sp.l: Sergeant, without the ceremony of O yes.
Pronounce aloud the proclamation.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: The Kings Justices, perceiving what public mischief may ensue this private quarrel in his majesties name do straightly charge and command all persons, of what degree soever, to depart this city of Hereford, except such as are bound to give attendance at this Assize, and that no man presume to wear any weapon, especially welsh-hooks, forest bills.

sp.speaker: Owen
sp.p: Haw, no pill nor wells hoog? ha?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Peace, and hear the proclamation.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: And that the Lord Powesse do presently disperse and discharge his retinue, and depart the city in the Kings peace, he and his followers, on pain of imprisonment.

sp.speaker: Dauy
sp.l: Haw? put her Lord Pawesse in prison, A Pawes
A Pawesse, cossone live and tie with her Lord.

sp.speaker: Gough
sp.p: A Herbert a Herbert.

stage.hi:
In this fight the Lord Herbert is wounded, and fals to the ground, the Maior and his company goe away crying clubbes, Powesse runnes away, Gough and other of Herberts faction busie themselues about Herbert: enters the two Iudges in their roabes,
the Sheriffe" and his Baileffes afore them, &c.

sp.speaker: 1. Iud.
sp.p: Where is the Lord Herbert? is he hurt or slain?

sp.speaker: Sher.
sp.p: He is here my Lord.

sp.speaker: 2. Iud.
sp.p: How fares hid Lordship, friends?

sp.speaker: Gough
sp.p: Mortally wounded, speechless, he cannot live.

sp.speaker: 1. Iud
sp.l: Convey him hence, let not his wounds take air,
And get him dressed with expedition,
M. Mayor of Hereford M Snriue of the shire,
Commit Lord Powesse to safe custody,
To answer the disturbance of the peace,
Lord Herberts peril, and his high contempt
Of us, and you the Kings commissioners,
See it be done with care and diligence.

sp.speaker: Sher.
sp.l: Please it your Lordship, my Lord Powesse is gone,
Past all recovery.

sp.speaker: 2. Iud.
sp.l: Yet let search be made,
To apprehend his followers that are left.

sp.speaker: Sher.
sp.p: There are some of them, sirs, lay hold on them,

sp.speaker: Owen
sp.p: Of us, and why? what has her done I pray you?

sp.speaker: Sher.
sp.p: Disarm them Bailiffs.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Officers assist.

sp.speaker: Dauy
sp.p: Hear you Lor Judge, what reason is for this?

sp.speaker: Owen
sp.p: Cosson pe puse for fighting for our Lord?

sp.speaker: 1. Iudge
sp.p: Away with them.

sp.speaker: Dauy
sp.p: Harg you my Lord.

sp.speaker: Owen
sp.p: Gough my Lord Herberts man is a shitten knave,

sp.speaker: Dauy
sp.p: I live and die in good quarrel.

sp.speaker: Owen
sp.p: Pray you do justice, let awl be prison.

sp.speaker: Dauy
sp.l: Prison no,
Lord judge I will give you pale, good surety.

sp.speaker: 2. Iudge
sp.p: What Bale? what sureties?

sp.speaker: Dauy
sp.p: Her cousin ap Ries, ap Euan, ap Morrice, ap Morgan, ap Lluellyn, ap Madoc, ap Meredith, ap Griffen, ap Dauy, ap Owen ap Shinken Shones.

sp.speaker: 2 Iudge.
sp.p: Two of the most, sufficient are enough,

sp.speaker: Sher.
sp.p: If it please your Lordship these are all but one.

sp.speaker: 1. Iudge
sp.l: To Jail with them, and the Lord Herberts men,
We will talk with them, when the Assize is done,
Riotous, audacious, and unruly Grooms,
Must we be forced to come from the Bench,
To quiet brawls, which every Constable
In other civil places can suppress?

sp.speaker: 2. Iudge
sp.p: What was the quarrel that caused all this stir?

sp.speaker: Sher.
sp.l: About religion (as I heard) my Lord.
Lord Powesse detracted from the power of Rome,
Affirming Wickliffes doctrine to be true,
And Rome's erroneous: hot reply was made
By the lord Herbert, they were traitors all
That would maintain it: Powesse answered,
They were as true, as noble, and as wise
As he, that would defend it with their lives,
He named for instance sir Iohn Old-castle
The Lord Cobham: Herbert replied again,
He, thou, and all are traitors that so hold.
Then he was given, the several factions drawn,
And so enraged, that we could not appease it.

sp.speaker: 1. Iudge
sp.l: This case concerns the Kings prerogative,
And it is dangerous to the State and common wealth.
Gentlemen, Justices, master Mayor, and master Shrieve,
It doth behove us all, and each of us
In general and particular, to have care
For the suppressing of all mutinies,
And all assemblies, except soldiers musters
For the Kings preparation into France.
We hear of secret conventicles made,
And there is doubt of some conspiracies,
Which may break out into rebellious arms
When the King is gone, perchance before he go:
Note as an instance, this one perilous fray,
What factions might have grown on either part,
To the destruction of the King and Realm,
Yet, in my conscience, sir Iohn Old-castle
Innocent of it, only his name was used.
We therefore from his Highness give this charge.
You master Mayor, look to your citizens,
You master Sheriff unto your shire, and you
As Justices in every ones precinct
There be no meetings. When the vulgar sort
Sit on their Ale-bench, with their cups and cans,
Matters of state be not their common talk,
Nor pure religion by their lips profaned.
Let us return unto the Bench again,
And there examine further of this fray.

div.stage: Enter a Baily and a Serieant

sp.speaker: Sher.
sp.p: Sirs, have ye taken the lord Powesse yet?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: No, nor heard of him.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: No, he is gone far enough.

sp.speaker: 2. Iu.
sp.p: They that are left behind, shall answer all.

div.stage: Enter Suffolke, Bishop of Rochester, Butler, parson of Wrotham.

sp.speaker: Suffolke
sp.l: Now my lord Bishop, take free liberty
To speak your mind: what is your suit to us?

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: My noble Lord, no more than what you know,
And have been oftentimes invested with:
Grievous complaints have past between the lips
Of envious persons to upbraid the Clergy,
Some carping at the livings which we have,
And others spurning at the ceremonies
That are of ancient custom in the church.
Amongst the which, Lord Cobham is a chief:
What inconvenience may proceed hereof,
Both to the King and to the common wealth,
May easily be discerned, when like a frenzy
This innovation shall possess their minds.
These upstarts will have followers to uphold
Their damned opinion, more than Harry shall
To undergo his quarrel against the French.

sp.speaker: Suffolke
sp.l: What proof is there against them to be had,
That what you say the law may justify?

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: They give themselves the name of Protestants,
And meet in fields and solitary groves.

sp.speaker: sir Ihon
sp.l: Was ever heard (my Lord) the like till now?
That thieves and rebels, sblood heretics,
Plain heretics, I will stand to it to their teeth,
Should have to colour, their vile practises,
A title of such worth, as Protestant?

sp.speaker: Suf.
sp.l: O but you must not swear, it ill becomes
One of your coat, to rap out bloody oaths.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.l: Pardon him good my Lord, it is his zeal,
An honest country prelate, who laments
To see such foul disorder in the church.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn
sp.l: There is one they call him Sir Iohn Old-castle,
He has not his name for nought: for like a castle
Doth he encompass them within his walls,
But till that castle be subverted quite,
We never shall be at quiet in the realm.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.l: That is our suit, my Lord, that he be taken,
And brought in question for his heresy,
Beside, two letters brought me out of Wales,
Wherein my Lord Herford writes to me,
What tumult and sedition was begun,
About the Lord Cobham, at the Assizes there,
For they had much ado to calm the rage,
And that the valiant Herbert is there slain.

sp.speaker: Suf.
sp.l: A fire that must be quenched; well, say no more,
The King anon goes to the counsel chamber,
There to debate of matters touching France:
As he doth pass by, I will inform his grace
Concerning your petition: Master Butler,
If I forget, do you remember me,

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: I will my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.l: Not for a recompense,
But as a token of our love to you,
By me my Lords of the clergy do present
This purse, and in it full a thousand Angels,
Praying your Lordship to accept their gift.

sp.speaker: Suf.
sp.l: I thank them, my Lord Bishop, for their love,
But will not take their money, if you please
To give it to this gentleman, you may.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.p: Sir, then we crave your furtherance herein.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: The best I can my Lord of Rochester.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.p: Nay, pray ye take it, trust me but you shall,

sp.l: Were ye all three upon New Market heath,
You should not need strain curtsy who should have it,
Sir Iohn would quickly rid ye of that care.

sp.speaker: Suf
sp.l: The King is coming, fear ye not my Lord,
The very first thing I will break with him,
Shall be about your matter.

div.stage: Enter K. Harry and Huntington in talke.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: My Lord of Suffolke,
Was it not said the Clergy did refuse
To lend us money toward our wars in France?

sp.speaker: Suf.
sp.p: It was my Lord, but very wrongfully.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: I know it was, for Huntington here tells me,
They have been very bountiful of late.

sp.speaker: Suf.
sp.l: And still they vow my gracious Lord to be so,
Hoping your majesty will think of them,
As of your loving subjects, and suppress
All such malicious errors as begin
To spot their calling, and disturb the church.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: God else forbid: why Suffolke, is there
Any new rupture to disquiet them?

sp.speaker: Suf.
sp.l: No new my Lord, the old is great enough,
And so increasing as if not cut down,
Will breed a scandal to your royal state,
And set your Kingdom quickly in an uproar,
The Kentish knight Lord Cobham, in despite
Of any law, or spiritual discipline,
Maintains this upstart new religion still,
And divers great assemblies by his means
And private quarrels, are commenced abroad,
As by this letter more at large my liege,
Is made apparent.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: We do find it here,
There was in Wales a certain fray of late,
Between two noblemen, but what of this?
Follows it straight Lord Cobham must be he
Did cause the same? I dare be sworn (good knight)
He never dreamt of any such contention.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.l: But in his name the quarrel did begin,
About the opinion which he held (my liege.)

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: How if it did? was either he in place,
To take part with them, or abet them in it?
If brabbling fellows, whose in kindled blood,
Seethes in their fiery veins, will needs go fight,
Making their quarrels of some words that passed,
Either of you, or you, amongst their cups,
Is the fault yours, or are they guilty of it?

sp.speaker: Suffolke
sp.l: With pardon of your Highness (my dread lord)
Such little sparks neglected, may in time
Grow to a mighty flame: but that is not all,
He doth beside maintain a strange religion,
And will not be compelled to come to mass.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.l: We do beseech you therefore gracious prince,
Without offence unto your majesty
We may be bold to use authority.

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: As how?

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: To summon him unto the Arches,
Where such offences have their punishment.

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: To answer personally, is that your meaning?

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.p: It is, my lord.

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: How if he appeal?

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.p: He cannot (my Lord) in such a case as this.

sp.speaker: Suffolke
sp.p: Not where Religion is the plea, my lord.

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.l: I took it always, that ourself stood out,
As a sufficient refuge, unto whom
Not any but might lawfully appeal.
But we will not argue now upon that point:
For sir Iohn Old-castle whom you accuse,
Let me entreat you to dispense awhile
With your high title of pre-eminence.
Report did never yet condemn him so,
But he hath always been reputed loyal:
And in my knowledge I can say thus much,
That he is virtuous, wise, and honourable:
If any way his conscience be seduced,
To waver in his faith: I will send for him,
And school him privately, if that serve not,
Then afterward you may proceed against him.
Butler, be you the messenger for us,
And will him presently repair to court.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.l: How now my lord, why stand you discontent?
In sooth, methinks the King hath well decreed.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: Yea, yea, sir Iohn, if he would keep his word,
But I perceive he favours him so much,
As this will be to small effect, I fear.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.l: Why then I will tell you what you are best to do:
If you suspect the King will be but cold
In reprehending him, send you a process too
To serve upon him: so you may be sure
To make him answer it, howsoever it fall.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: And well remembered, I will have it so,
A Summoner shall be sent about it strait

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.l: Yea, do so, in the mean space this remains
For kind sir Iohn of Wrotham honest Iacke.
Methinks the purse of gold the Bishop gave,
Made a good show, it had a tempting look,
Beshrew me, but my fingers ends do itch
To be upon those rudduks: well, it is thus:
I am not as the world does take me for:
If ever wolf were clothed in sheeps coat,
Then I am he, old huddle and twang, in faith,
A priest in show, but in plain terms, a thief,
Yet let me tell you too, an honest thief.
One that will take it where it may besp.
And spend it freely in good fellowship.
I have as many shapes as Proteus had,
That still when any villainy is done,
There may be none suspect it was sir Iohn.
Besides, to comfort me, for what is this life,
Except the crabbed bitterness thereof
Be sweetened now and then with lechery?
I have my Doll, my concubine as it were,
To frolic with, a lusty bouncing girl.
But whilst I loiter here the gold, may scape,
And that must not be so, it is mine own,
Therefore I will meet him on his way to court,
And shrive him of it: there will be the sport.

div.stage: Enter three or foure poore people, some souldiers, some old men.

sp.l: God help, God help, there is law for punishing,
But there is no law for our necessity:
There be more stocks to set poor soldiers in,
Than there be houses to relieve them at.

sp.speaker: Old man
sp.l: Faith, housekeeping decays in every place,
Even as Saint Peter writ, still worse and worse

sp.p: Master mayor of Rochester has given commandment, that none shall go abroad out of the parish, and they have set an order down forsooth, what every poor householder must give towards our relief: where there be some ceased I may say to you, had almost as much need to beg as we.
It is a hard world the while.

sp.speaker: Old man

sp.p: Faith we have none, but what we bear upon our bodies, our maimed limbs, God help us.

sp.speaker: Olde man.
sp.p:
Ha, were I but as lusty as I was at the battle of Shrewsbury, I would not do as I do: but we are now come to the good lord Cobhams, to the best man to the poor that
is in all Kent.
God bless him, there be but few such.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Thou peevish froward man, what wouldst thou have?

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.l: This pride, this pride, brings all to beggary,
I served your father, and your grandfather,
Show me such two men now: no, no,
Your backs, your backs, the devil and pride,
Has cut the throat of all good housekeeping,
They were the best Yeoman's masters, that
Ever were in England.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: Yea, except thou have a crew of silly knaves,
And sturdy rogues, still feeding at my gate,
There is no hospitality with thee.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: They may sit at the gate well enough, but the devil of anything you give them, except they will eat stones.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: It is long then of such hungry knaves as you,
Yea sir, here is your retinue, your guests be come,
They know their hours I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: God bless your honour, God save the good Lord Cobham, and all his house,

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: Good your honour, bestow your blessed alms,
Upon poor men.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: Now sir, here be your Alms knights.
Now are you as safe as the Emperor.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.l: My Alms knights: nay, they are yours,
It is a shame for you, and I will stand to it,
Your foolish alms maintains more vagabonds,
Than all the noblemen in Kent beside.
Out you rogues, you knaves, work for your livings,
Alas poor men, O Lord, they may beg their hearts out,
There is no more charity amongst men,
Than amongst so many mastiff dogs,
What make you here, you needy knaves?
Away, away, you villains.

sp.speaker: 2. soul.
sp.p: I beseech you sit, be good to us.

sp.speaker: Cobham
sp.p: Nay, nay, they know thee well enough, I think that all the beggars in this land are thy acquaintance, go bestow your alms, none will control you sir.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: What should I give them? you are grown so beggarly, you have scarce a bit of bread to give at your door: you talk of your religion so long, that you have banished charity from amongst you, a man may make a flax shop in your kitchen chimneys, for any fire there is stirring.

sp.speaker: Cobham
sp.p: If thou wilt give them nothing, send them hence, let them not stand here starving in the cold.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Who I drive them hence? if I drive poor men from your door, I will be hanged, I know not what I may come tomyself: yea, God help you poor knaves, ye see the world in faith, well, you had a mother: well, God be with thee good Lady, thy soul is at rest: she gave more in shirts and smocks to poor children, than you spend in your house, and yet you live a beggar too.

sp.speaker: Cobham
sp.p: Even the worst deed that ere my mother did, was in relieving such a fool as thou.

sp.speaker: Harpoole
sp.p: Yea, yea, I am a fool still, with all your wit you will die a beggar, go too.

sp.speaker: Cobham
sp.p: Go you old fool, give the poor people something, go in poor men into the inner court, and take such alms as there is to be had.

sp.speaker: Souldier
sp.p: God bless your honour.

sp.speaker: Harpoole
sp.p: Hang you rogues, hang you, there is nothing but misery amongst you, you fear no law you.

sp.speaker: Olde man
sp.p: God bless you good master Rafe, God save your life, you are good to the poor still.

div.stage: Enter the Lord Powes disguised, and shrowde himselfe.

sp.speaker: Cobham
sp.l: What fellow is yonder comes along the grove?
Few passengers there be that know this way:
Methinks he stops as though he stayed for me,
And meant to shroud himself amongst the bushes.
I know the Clergy hate me to the death,
And my religion gets me many foes:
And this may be some desperate rogue,
Suborned to work me mischief: As it
Pleaseth God, if he come toward me, sure
I will stay his coming, be he but one man,
What soever he be:
I have been well acquainted with that face.

sp.speaker: Powis
sp.p: Well met my honourable lord and friend.

sp.speaker: Cobham
sp.l: You are welcome sir, what ere you be,
But of this sudden sir, I do not know you.

sp.speaker: Powis
sp.l: I am one that wisheth well unto your honour,
My name is Powes, an old friend of yours.

sp.speaker: Cobham
sp.l: My honourable lord, and worthy friend,
What makes your lordship thus alone in Kent,
And thus disguised in this strange attire?

sp.speaker: Powis
sp.l: My Lord, an unexpected accident,
Hath at this time enforced me to these parts:
And thus it happed, not yet full five days since,
Now at the last Assize at Hereford,
It chanced that the lord Herbert and myself,
Amongst other things, discoursing at the table,
To fall in speech about some certain points
Of Wickcliffes doctrine, against the papacy,
And the religion catholic, maintained
Through the most part of Europe at this day.
This wilful testy lord stuck not to say,
That Wickcliffe was a knave, a schismatics,
His doctrine devilish and heretical,
And what soever he was maintained the same,
was traitor both to God and to his country.
Being moved at his peremptory speech,
I told him, some maintained those opinions,
Men, and truer subjects than lord Herbert was:
And he replying in comparisons:
Your name was urged, my lord, against his challenge,
To be a perfect favourer of the truth.
And to be short, from words we fell to blows,
Our servants, and our tenants taking parts,
Many on both sides hurt: and for an hour
The broil by no means could be pacified,
Until the Judges rising from the bench,
Were in their persons forced to part the fray.

sp.speaker: Cobham
sp.p: I hope no man was violently slain.

sp.speaker: Powis
sp.l: Faith none I trust, but the lord Herberts self,
Who is in truth so dangerously hurt,
As it is doubted he can hardly scape.

sp.speaker: Cobham
sp.p: I am sorry, my good lord, of these ill news.

sp.speaker: Powis
sp.l: This is the cause that drives me into Kent,
To shroud myself with you so good a friend,
Until I hear how things do speed at home.

sp.speaker: Cobham
sp.l: Your lordship is most welcome unto Cobham,
But I am very sorry, my good lord,
My name was brought in question in this matter,
Considering I have many enemies,
That threaten malice, and do lie in wait
To take advantage of the smallest thing.
But you are welcome, and repose your lordship,
And keep yourself here secret in my house,
Until we hear how the lord Herbert speeds:
Here comes my man.
Sirrah, what news?

sp.speaker: Harpoole
sp.p: Yonder is one master Butler of the privy chamber, is sent unto you from the King.

sp.speaker: Powis
sp.p: I pray God the lord Herbert be not dead, and the King hearing whither I am gone, hath sent for me.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Comfort yourself my lord, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Harpoole
sp.p: Fellow, what ails thee? doest thou quake? dost thou shake? dost thou tremble? ha?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Peace you old fool, sirrah, convey this gentleman in the back way, and bring the other into the walk.

sp.speaker: Harpoole
sp.p: Come sir. you are welcome, if you love my lord.

sp.speaker: Powis
sp.p: God have mercy gentle friend.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p:
I thought as much, that it would not be long before I
heard of something from the King, about this matter.

sp.speaker: Harpoole
sp.l: Sir, yonder my lord walks, you see him,
I will have your men into the Cellar the while.

sp.speaker: Cobh.
sp.p: welcome good master Butler.

sp.speaker: Butler
sp.p: Thanks, my good lord: his Majesty doth commend his love unto your lordship, and wills you to repair unto the court.

sp.speaker: Cobh.
sp.p: God bless his Highness, and confound his enemies, I hope his Majesty is well.

sp.speaker: Butler
sp.p: In health, my lord.

sp.speaker: Cobh.
sp.p: God long continue it: methinks you look as though you were not well, what ails you sir?

sp.speaker: Butler
sp.p: Faith I have had a foolish odd mischance, that angers me: coming over Shooters hill, there came a fellow to me like a Sailor, and asked me money, and whilst I staid my horse to draw my purse, he takes the advantage of a little bank and leaps behind me, whips my purse away, and with a sudden jerk I know not how, threw me at least three yards out of my saddle. I never was so robbed in all my life.

sp.speaker: Cobh.
sp.p: I am very sorry sir for your mischance, we will send our warrant forth, to stay such suspicious persons as shall be found, then master Butler, we will attend you.

sp.speaker: Butler
sp.p: I humbly thank your lordship, I will attend you.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: I have the law to warrant what I do, and though the Lord Cobham be a noble man, that dispenses not with law, I dare serve process were a five noble men, though we Summoners make sometimes a mad slip in a corner with a pretty wench, a Summoner must not go always by seeing, a man may be content to hide his eyes, where he may feel his profit: well, this is my Lord Cobhams house, if I can devise to speak with him, if not, I will clap my citation upon his door, so my lord of Rochester bid me, but methinks here comes one of his men.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p:
Welcome good fellow, welcome, who wouldst thou
speak with?

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: With my lord Cobham, I would speak, if thou be one of his men.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Yes I am one of his men, but thou canst not speak with my lord.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: May I send to him them?

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: I will tell thee that, when I know thy errand.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: I will not tell my errand to thee.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Then keep it to thyself, and walk like a knave as thou camest.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: I tell thee my lord keeps no knaves, sirrah.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Then thou servest him not, I believe, what lord is thy master?

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: My lord of Rochester.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: In good time, and what wouldst thou have with my lord Cobham?

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: I come by virtue of a process, to ascite him to appear before my lord, in the court at Rochester.

sp.speaker: Harp
sp.p: Well, God grant me patience, I could eat this conger. My lord is not at home, therefore it were good Summoner you carried your process back.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: Why, if he will not be spoken withal, then will I leave it here, and see you that he take knowledge of it.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: 'swounds you slave, do you set up your bills here, go to, take it down again, doest thou know what thou dost, dost thee know on whom thou servest process?

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: Yes marry do I, Sir Iohn Old-castle Lord Cobham.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: I am glad thou knowest him yet, and sirrah dost not thou know, that the lord Cobham is a brave lord, that keeps good beef and beer in his house, and every day feeds a hundred poor people at his gate, and keeps a hundred tall fellows?

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: What is that to my process?

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Mary this sir, is this process parchment?

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: Yes mary.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: And this seal wax?

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: It is so.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: If this be parchment, and this wax, eat you this parchment, and this wax, or I will make parchment of your skin, and beat your brains into wax: Sirrah Summoner dispatch, devour, sirrah devour.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: I am my lord of Rochesters Summoner, I came to do my office, and thou shalt answer it.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Sirrah, no railing, but betake you to your teeth, thou shalt eat no worse than thou bringest with thee, thou bringest it for my lord, and wilt thou bring my lord worse than thou wilt eat thyself?

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: Sir, I brought it not my lord to eat.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: O do you sir me now, all is one for that, but I will make you eat it, for bringing it.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: I cannot eat it.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Can you not? 'sblood I will beat you until you have a stomach.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: O hold, hold, good master serving-man, I will eat it.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Be champing, be chewing sir, or I will chew you, you rogue, the purest of the honey.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: Tough wax, is the purest of the honey.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.l: O Lord sir, o o,
Feed, feed, wholesome rogue, wholesome.
sp.p: Cannot you like an honest Summoner walk with the devil your brother, to fetch in your Bailiffs rents, but you must come to a noble man's house with process? 'sblood if thy seal were as broad as the lead that covers Rochester church, thou shouldest eat it.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: O I am almost choked, I am almost choked.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Who is within there? will you shame my Lord, is there no beer in the house? Butler I say.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Hear, here.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.l: Give him Beer.
There, tough old sheepskins, bare dry meat.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: O sir, let me go no further, I will eat my word.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Yea mary sir, so I mean you shall eat more than your own word, for I will make you eat all the words in the process. Why you drab monger, cannot the secrets of all the wenches in a shire serve your turn, but you must come hither with a citation with a pox? I will cite you.
A cup of sack for the Summoner.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Here sir here.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Here slave I drink to thee.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: I thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Now if thou findest thy stomach well, because thou shalt see my Lord keep his meat in his house, if thou wilt go in thou shalt have a piece of beef to thy break fast.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: No I am very well good M. serving-man, I thank you, very well sir.

sp.speaker: Harp.
Sum.
sp.p: God be with you M. serving-man.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Farewell Sumner.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: God save you M. Harpoole.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Welcome Constable, welcome Constable, what news with thee?

sp.speaker: Con.
Harp.
sp.p: Hast thou been at the Alehouse, hast thou sought there?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I durst not search sir, in my Lord Cobhams liberty, except I had some of his servants, which are for my warrant.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: An honest Constable, an honest Constable, call forth him that keeps the Alehouse there.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Ho, who is within there?

sp.speaker: Ale man
sp.p:
Who calls there, come near a Gods name, o is it
you M. Constable and M. Harpoole, you are welcome with all my heart, what make you here so early this morning?

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Sirrah, what strangers do you lodge, there is a robbery done this morning, and we are to search for all suspected persons.

sp.speaker: Aleman.
sp.p: Gods bores, I am sorry for it, in faith sir I lodge nobody but a good honest merry priest, they call him sir Iohn a Wrootham, and a handsome woman that is his niece, that he says he has some suit in law for, and as they go up and down to London, sometimes they lie at my house.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: What, is he here in thy house now?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: She is sir, I promise you sir he is a quiet man, and because he will not trouble too many rooms, he makes the woman lie every night at his beds feet.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Bring her forth Constable, bring her forth, let us see her, let us see her.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Dorothy, you must come down to M. Constable.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Anon forsooth.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Welcome sweet lass, welcome.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: I thank you good M. serving-man, and master Constable also.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: A plump girl by the mass, a plump girl, ha Dol ha, wilt thou forsake the priest, and go with me.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: A well said M. Harpoole, you are a merry old man in faith, in faith you will never be old: now by the macke, a pretty wench indeed.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Ye old mad merry Constable, art thou advised of that ha, well said Dol, fill some ale here.

sp.speaker: Dol
sp.p: O if I wist this old priest would not stick to me, by Ioue I would ingle this old serving-man.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: O you old mad colt, in faith I will feak you: fill all the pots in the house there.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: O well said M. Harpoole, you are heart of oak when all is done.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Ha Dol, thou hast a sweet pair of lips by the mass.

sp.speaker: Doll
sp.p: Truly you are a most sweet old man, as ever I saw, by my troth, you have a face, able to make any woman in love with you.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Fill sweet Doll, I will drink to thee.

sp.speaker: Doll
sp.p: I pledge you sir, and thank you therefore, and I pray you let it come.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Doll, canst thou love me? a mad merry lass, would to God I had never seen thee.

sp.speaker: Doll
sp.p: I warrant you you will not out of my thoughts this twelve-month, truly you are as full of favour, as a man may be. Ah these sweet grey locks, by my troth, they are most lovely.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: Gods boars master Harpoole, I will have one buss too.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: No licking for you Constable, hand off, hand off.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: Byrlady I love kissing as well as you.

sp.speaker: Doll
sp.p: O you are an odd boy, you have a wanton eye of your own: ah you sweet sugar lipped wanton, you will win as many women's hearts as come in your company.

sp.speaker: Wroth.
sp.p: Doll, come hither.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Priest, she shall not.

sp.speaker: Doll
sp.p: I will come anon, sweet love.

sp.speaker: Wroth.
sp.p: Hand off, old fornicator.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Vicar, I will sit here in spite of thee, is this fit stuff for a priest to carry up and down with him?

sp.speaker: Wrotham
sp.p: Ah sirrah, dost thou not know, that a good fellow parson may have a chapel of ease, where his parish Church is far off?

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: You whoreson stoned Vicar.

sp.speaker: Wroth.
sp.p: You old stale ruffian, you lion of Cotswold.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: 'swounds Vicar, I will geld you.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: Keep the Kings peace.

sp.speaker: Doll
sp.p: Murder, murder, murder.

sp.speaker: Ale man
sp.p: Hold, as you are men, hold, for Gods sake be quiet: put up your weapons, you draw not in my house.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: You whoreson bawdy priest.

sp.speaker: Wroth.
sp.p: You old mutton monger.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: Hold sir Iohn, hold.

sp.speaker: Doll to the Priest
sp.p: I pray thee sweet heart be quiet, I was but sitting to drink a pot of ale with him, even as kind a man as ever I met with.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Thou art a thief I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Wroth.
Doll
sp.p: Come, be quiet, hast thou sped?

sp.speaker: Wroth.
sp.p: I have wench, here be crowns i'faith.

sp.speaker: Doll
sp.p: Come, let us be all friends then.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: Well said mistress Dorothy i'faith.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Thou art the madest priest that ever I met with.

sp.speaker: Wroth.
sp.p: Give me thy hand, thou art as good a fellow, I am a singer, a drinker, a bencher, a wencher, I can say a mass, and kiss a lass: faith I have a parsonage, and because I would not be at too much charges, this wench serves me for a sexton.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Well said mad priest, we will in and be friends,

div.stage: Enter sir Roger Acton, master Bourne, master Beuerley, and William Murley the brewer of Dunstable.

sp.speaker: Acton
sp.l: Now master Murley, I am well assured
You know our arrant, and do like the cause,
Being a man affected as we are?

sp.speaker: Mu.
sp.p: Mary God dild ye dainty my dear, no master, good Sir Roger Acton Knight, master Bourne, and master Beuerley esquires, gentlemen, and justices of the peace, no master I, but plain William Murly the brewer of Dunstable your honest neighbour, and your friend, if ye be men of my profession.

sp.speaker: Beuerley
sp.p: Professed friends to Wickliffe, foes to Rome.

sp.speaker: Murl.
sp.p: Hold by me lad, lean upon that staff good master Beuerley, all of a house, say your mind, say your mind.

sp.speaker: Acton
sp.l: You know our faction now is grown so great,
Throughout the realm; that it begins to smoke
Into the Clergies eyes, and the Kings ears,
High time it is that we were drawn to head,
Our general and officers appointed.
And wars ye wot will ask great store of coin.
Able to strength our action with your purse,
You are elected for a colonel
Over a regiment of fifteen bands.

sp.speaker: Murley
sp.p: Fue paltry paltry, in and out, to and fro, be it more or less, upon occasion, Lord have mercy upon us, what a world is this? Sir Roger Acton, I am but a Dunstable man, a plain brewer, ye know: will lusty Cavaliering captains gentlemen come at my calling, go at my bidding? Dainty my dear, they will do a dog of wax, a horse of cheese, a prick and a pudding, no, no, ye must appoint some lord or knight at least to that place.

sp.speaker: Bourne
sp.l: Why master Murley, you shall be a Knight:
Were you not in election to be shrieve?
Have ye not past all offices but that?
Have ye not wealth to make your wife a lady?
I warrant you, my lord, our General
Bestows that honour on you at first sight.

sp.speaker: Murley
sp.l: Mary God dild ye dainty my dear:
But tell me, who shall be our General?
Wheres the lord Cobham, sir Iohn Old-castle,
That noble alms-giver, housekeeper, virtuous,
Religious gentleman? Come to me there boys,
Come to me there.

sp.speaker: Acton
sp.p: Why who but he shall be our General?

sp.speaker: Murley
sp.p: And shall he knight me, and make me colonel?

sp.speaker: Acton
sp.p: My word for that, sir William Murley knight.

sp.speaker: Murley
sp.p: Fellow sir Roger Acton knight, all fellows, I mean in arms, how strong are we? how many partners? our enemies beside the King are mighty, be it more or less upon occasion, reckon our force.

sp.speaker: Acton
sp.l: There are of us, our friends, and followers,
Three thousand and three hundred at the least,
Of northern lads four thousand, beside horse,
From Kent there comes with sir Iohn Old-castle
Seven thousand, then from London issue out,
Of masters, servants, strangers, prentices
Forty odd thousands into Ficket field,
Where we appoint our special rendezvous.

sp.speaker: Mur
sp.p: Fue, paltry, in and out to and fro, Lord have mercy, what a world is this, wheres that Ficket field, sir Roger?

sp.speaker: Acton
sp.p: Behind saint Giles in the field near Holborne.

sp.speaker: Murley
sp.p: Newgate, up Holborne, Saint Giles in the field, and to Tiborne, an old saw: for the day, for the day?

sp.speaker: Acton
sp.p: On friday next the fourteenth day of January.

sp.speaker: Murley
sp.p: Tilly-Vally, trust me never if I have any liking of that day: fue paltry paltry, friday quoth he, dismal day, Childermas day this year was friday.

sp.speaker: Beuerley
sp.l: Nay master Murley, if you observe such days,
We make some question of your constancy,
All days are like to men resolved in right.

sp.speaker: Murley
sp.p: Say Amen, and say no more, but say, and hold master Beuerley, friday next, and Ficket field, and William Murley, and his merry men shall be all one, I have half a score jades that draw my beer carts, and every jade shall bear a knave, and every knave shall wear a iacke, and every iacke shall have a scull, and every scull shall show a spear, and every spear shall kill a foe at Ficket field, at Ficket field, Iohn and Tom, and Dicke and Hodge, and Rafe and Robin, William and George, and all my knaves shall fight like men, at Ficket field on friday next.

sp.speaker: Bourne
sp.p: What sum of money mean you to disburse?

sp.speaker: Murley
sp.p: It may be modestly, decently, soberly, and handsomely I may bring five hundredth pound.

sp.speaker: Acton
sp.l: Five hundredth man? five thousand is not enough,
A hundredth thousand will not pay our men
Two months together, either come prepared
Like a brave Knight, and martial Colonel,
In glittering gold, and gallant furniture,
Bringing in coin, a cart load at the least,
And all your followers mounted on good horse,
Or never come disgraceful to us all.

sp.speaker: Beuerley
sp.l: Perchance you may be chosen Treasurer,
Ten thousand pounds the least that you can bring.

sp.speaker: Murley
sp.p: Paltry paltry, in and out, to and fro, upon occasion I have ten thousand pound to spend, and then too. And rather than the Bishop shall have his will of me for my conscience, it shall out all. Flame and flax, flame and flax, it was got with water and malt, and it shall fly with fire and gun powder. Sir Roger, a cart load of money till the axetree crack,myself and my men in Ficket field on friday next: remember my Knighthood, and my place: there is my hand I will be there.

sp.speaker: Acton
sp.l: See what Ambition may persuade men to,
In hope of honour he will spend himself.

sp.speaker: Bourne
sp.p: I never thought a Brewer half so rich.

sp.speaker: Beuerley
sp.l: Was never bankrupt Brewer yet but one,
With using too much malt, too little water.

sp.speaker: Acton
sp.l: That is no fault in Brewers nowadays:
Come, away about our business.

div.stage: Enter K. Harry, Suffolke, Butler, and Old-castle kneeling to the King.

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.l: It is not enough Lord Cobham to submit.
You must forsake your gross opinion,
The Bishops find themselves much injured,
And though for some good service you have done,
We for our part are pleased to pardon you,
Yet they will not so soon be satisfied,

sp.speaker: Cobham
sp.l: My gracious Lord unto your Majesty,
Next unto my God, I owe my life,
And what is mine, either by natures gift,
Or fortunes bounty, all is at your service,
But for obedience to the Pope of Rome,
I owe him none, nor shall his shaveling priests
That are in England, alter my belief.
If out of holy Scripture they can prove,
That I am in an error, I will yield,
And gladly take instruction at their hands,
But otherwise, I do beseech your grace,
My conscience may not be encroached upon.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: We would be loath to press our subjects bodies,
Much less their souls, the dear redeemed part,
Of him that is the ruler of us all,
Yet let me counsel ye, that might command,
Do not presume to tempt them with ill words,
Nor suffer any meetings to be had
Within your house, but to the uttermost,
Disperse the flocks of this new gathering sect.

sp.speaker: Cobham
sp.l: My liege, if any breathe, that dares come forth,
And say, my life in any of these points
Deserves the attaindor of ignoble thoughts
Here stand I, craving no remorse at all,
But even the utmost rigour may be shown.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Let it suffice we know your loyalty,
What have you there?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: A deed of clemency,
Your Highness pardon for Lord Powesse life,
Which I did beg, and you my noble Lord,
Of gracious favour did vouchsafe to grant.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: But yet it is not signed with our hand.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Not yet my Liege.

div.stage: one ready with pen and incke.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: The fact, you say, was done,
Not of prepensed malice, but by chance.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Upon mine honour so, no otherwise.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: There is his pardon, bid him make amends,
And cleanse his soul to God for his offence,
What we remit, is but the bodies scourge,
How now Lord Bishop?

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: Justice dread Sovereign.
As thou art King, so grant I may have justice.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: What means this exclamation, let us know?

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.l: Ah my good Lord, the state is abused,
And our decrees most shamefully profaned.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: How, or by whom?

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.l: Even by this heretic,
This Jew, this Traitor to your majesty.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: Prelate, thou liest, even in thy greasy maw,
Or whosoever twits me with the name,
Of either traitor, or of heretic.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Forbear I say, and Bishop, show the cause
From whence this late abuse hath been derived,

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.l: Thus mighty King, by general consent,
A messenger was sent to cite this Lord,
To make appearance in the consistory,
And coming to his house, a ruffian slave,
One of his daily followers, met the man,
Who knowing him to be a paritor,
Assaults him first, and after in contempt
Of us, and our proceedings, makes him eat
The written process, parchment, seal and all:
Whereby his master neither was brought forth,
Nor we but scorned, for our authority.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: When was this done?

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.p: At six a clock this morning.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: And when came you to court?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Last night my Lord.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: By this it seems, he is not guilty of it,
And you have done him wrong to accuse him so.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.l: But it was done my lord by his appointment,
Or else his man durst never have been so bold.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Or else you durst be bold, to interrupt,
And fill our ears with frivolous complaints,
Is this the duty you do bear to us?
Was it not sufficient we did pass our word
To send for him, but you misdoubting it,
Or which is worse, intending to forestall
Our regal power, must likewise summon him?
This savours of Ambition, not of zeal,
And rather proves, you malice his estate,
Than any way that he offends the law.
Go to, we like it not, and he your officer,
That was employed so much amiss herein,
Had his desert for being insolent:
So Cobham when you please you may depart.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: I humbly bid farewell unto my liege.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Farewell, what is the news by Huntington?

sp.speaker: Hunt.
sp.l: Sir Roger Acton, and a crew, my Lord,
Of bold seditious rebels, are in Arms,
Intending reformation of Religion.
And with their Army they intend to pitch,
In Ficket field, unless they be repulsed.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: So near our presence? dare they be so bold?
And will proud war, and eager thirst of blood,
Whom we had thought to entertain far off,
Press forth upon us in our native bounds?
Must we be forced to handsel our sharp blades
In England here, which we prepared for France?
Well, in Gods name be it, what is their number? say,
Or who is the chief commander of this rout?

sp.speaker: Hunt.
sp.l: Their number is not known, as yet (my Lord)
But it is reported Sir Iohn Old-castle
Is the chief man, on whom they do depend.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: How, the Lord Cobham?

sp.speaker: Hunt.
sp.p: Yes my gracious Lord.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.l: I could have told your majesty as much
Before he went, but that I saw your Grace
Was too much blinded by his flattery.

sp.speaker: Suf.
sp.p: Send post my Lord to fetch him back again.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Traitor unto his country, how he smoothed,
And seemed as innocent as Truth itself?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: I cannot think it yet, he would be false,
But if he be, no matter let him go,
We will meet both him and them unto their woe.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.l: This falls out well, and at the last I hope
To see this heretic die in a rope.

div.stage: Enter Earle of Cambridge, Lord Scroope, Gray, and Chartres the French factor.

sp.speaker: Scroop.
sp.l: Once more my Lord of Cambridge make rehearsal,
How you do stand entitled to the Crown,
The deeper shall we print it in our minds,
And every man the better be resolved,
When he perceives his quarrel to be just.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Then thus Lord Scroope, sir Thomas Gray, and you
Monsieur de Chartres, agent for the French,
This Lionell Duke of Clarence, as I said,
Third son of Edward (Englands King) the third
Had issue Phillip his sole daughter and heir,
Which Phillip afterward was given in marriage,
To Edmund Mortimer the Earl of March,
And by him had a son called Roger Mortimer,
Which Roger likewise had of his descent,
Edmund, Roger, Anne, and Elianor,
Two daughters and two sons, but those three
Died without issue, Anne that did survive,
And now was left her fathers only heir,
My fortune was to marry, being too
By my grandfather of King Edwardes line,
So of his surname, I am called you know,
Richard Plantagenet, my father was,
Edward the Duke of Yorke, and son and heir
To Edmund Langley, Edward the third's first son.

sp.speaker: Scroop
sp.l: So that it seems your claim comes by your wife,
As lawful heir to Roger Mortimer,
The son of Edmund, which did marry Phillip
Daughter and heir to Lyonell Duke of Clarence.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: True, for this Harry, and his father both
Harry the first, as plainly doth appear,
Are false intruders, and usurp the Crown.
For when young Richard was at Pomfret slain,
In him the title of prince Edward died,
That was the eldest of king Edwards sons:
William of Hatfield, and their second brother,
Death in his nonage had before bereft:
So that my wife derived from Lionell,
Third son unto king Edward, ought proceed,
And take possession of the Diadem
Before this Harry, or his father king,
Who fetched their title but from Lancaster,
Forth of that royal line. And being thus,
What reason is it but she should have her right?

sp.speaker: Scroope
sp.p: I am resolved our enterprise is just.

sp.speaker: Gray
sp.p: Harry shall die, or else resign his crown.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.l: Perform but that, and Charles the king of France
Shall aid you lords, not only with his men,
But send you money to maintain your wars,
Five hundred thousand crowns he bade me proffer,
If you can stop but Harries voyage for France.

sp.speaker: Scrope
sp.l: We never had a fitter time than now
The realm in such division as it is.

sp.speaker: Camb.
sp.l: Besides, you must persuade ye there is due,
Vengeance for Richards murder, which although
It be defend, yet will it fall at last,
And now as likely as another time.
Sin hath had many years to ripen in,
And now the harvest cannot be far off,
Wherein the weeds of usurpation,
Are to be cropped, and cast into the fire.

sp.speaker: Scroope
sp.l: No more earl Cambridge, here I plight my faith,
To set up thee, and thy renowned wife.

sp.p: Gray will perform the same, as he is knight.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.l: And to assist ye, as I said before,
Charters doth gage the honour of his king.
We lack but now Lord Cobhams fellowship,
And then our plot were absolute indeed.

sp.speaker: Camb.
sp.l: Doubt not of him, my lord, his life is pursued
By the incensed Clergy, and of late,
Brought in displeasure with the king, assures
He may be quickly won unto our faction.
Who hath the articles were drawn at large
Of our whole purpose?

sp.speaker: Gray
sp.p: That have I my Lord.

sp.speaker: Camb.
sp.l: We should not now be far off from his house,
Our serious conference hath beguiled the way,
See where his castle stands, give me the writing.
When we are come unto the speech of him,
Because we will not stand to make recount,
Of that which hath been said, here he shall read
Our minds at large, and what we crave of him.

sp.speaker: Scroope
sp.l: A ready way: here comes the man himself
Booted and spurred, it seems he hath been riding.

sp.speaker: Camb.
sp.p: Well met lord Cobham.

sp.speaker: Cobh.
sp.l: My lord of Cambridge?
Your honour is most welcome into Kent,
And all the rest of this fair company.
I am new come from London, gentle Lords:
But will ye not take Cowling for your host,
And see what entertainment it affords?

sp.speaker: Camb.
sp.l: We were intended to have been your guests:
But now this lucky meeting shall suffice
To end our business, and defer that kindness.

sp.speaker: Cobh.
sp.l: Business my lord? what business should you have
But to be merry? we have no delicates,
But this I will promise you, a piece of venison,
A cup of wine, and so forth: hunters fare:
And if you please, we will strike the stag ourselves
Shall fill our dishes with his well-fed flesh.

sp.speaker: Scroope
sp.p: That is indeed the thing we all desire.

sp.speaker: Cobh.
sp.p: My lords, and you shall have your choice with me.

sp.speaker: Camb.
sp.l: Nay but the stag which we desire to strike,
Lives not in Cowling: if you will consent,
And go with us, we will bring you to a forest,
Where runs a lusty herd: amongst the which
There is a stag superior to the rest,
A stately beast, that when his fellows run,
He leads the race, and beats the sullen earth,
As though he scorned it with his trampling hooves,
Aloft he bears his head, and with his breast,
Like a huge bulwark counter-checks the wind:
And when he standeth still, he stretcheth forth
His proud ambitious neck, as if he meant
To wound the firmament with forked horns.

sp.speaker: Cobh.
sp.p: It is pity such a goodly beast should die.

sp.speaker: Camb.
sp.l: Not so, sir Iohn, for he is tyrannous,
And gores the other dear, and will not keep
Within the limits are appointed him.
Of late he is broke into a several,
Which doth belong to me, and there he spoils
Both corn and pasture, two of his wild race
Alike for stealth, and covetous encroaching,
Already are removed, if he were dead,
I should not only be secure from hurt,
But with his body make a royal feast.

sp.speaker: Scroope
sp.p: How say you then, will you first hunt with us?

sp.speaker: Cobh.
sp.p: Faith Lords, I like the pastime, wheres the place?

sp.speaker: Camb.
sp.l: Peruse this writing, it will show you all,
And what occasion we have for the sport.

sp.speaker: Cobh.
sp.l: Call ye this hunting, my lords? Is this the stag
You fain would chase, Harry our dread king?
So we may make a banquet for the devil,
And in the fleede of wholesome meat, prepare
A dish of poison to confound ourselves.

sp.speaker: Camb.
sp.l: Why so lord Cobham? see you not our claim?
And how imperiously he holds the crown?

sp.speaker: Scroope
sp.l: Besides, you know yourself is in disgrace,
Held as a recreant, and pursued to death.
This will defend you from your enemies,
And stablish your religion through the land.

sp.speaker: Cobh.
sp.l: Notorious treason! yet I will conceal
My secret thoughts, to sound the depth of it.
My lord of Cambridge, I do see your claim,
And what good may redound unto the land,
By prosecuting of this enterprise.
But where are men? where is power and furniture
To order such an action? we are weak,
Harry, you know is a mighty potentate.

sp.speaker: Camb.
sp.l: Tut, we are strong enough, you are beloved,
And many will be glad to follow you,
We are the light, and some will follow us:
Besides, there is hope from France: here is an ambassador
That promiseth both men and money too.
The commons likewise (as we hear) pretend
A sudden tumult, we will join with them.

sp.speaker: Cobh.
sp.l: Some likelihood, I must confess, to speed:
But how shall I believe this is plain truth?
You are (my lords) such men as live in Court,
And highly have been favoured of the king,
Especially lord Scroope, whom oftentimes
He maketh choice of for his bedfellow.
And you lord Gray are of his privy council:
Is not this a train to entrap my life?

sp.speaker: Camb.
sp.p: Then perish may my soul: what think you so?

sp.speaker: Scroope
sp.p: We will swear to you.

sp.speaker: Gray
sp.p: Or take the sacrament.

sp.speaker: Cobh.
sp.l: Nay you are noble men, and I imagine,
As you are honourable by birth and blood,
So you will be in heart, in thought, in word.
I crave no other testimony but this.
That you would all subscribe, and set your hands
Unto this writing which you gave to me.

sp.speaker: Camb.
sp.p: With all our hearts: who hath any pen and ink?

sp.speaker: Scroope
sp.p: My pocket should have one: yea, hear it is.

sp.speaker: Camb.
sp.p: Give it me lord Scroope: there is my name.

sp.speaker: Scroope
sp.p: And there is my name.

sp.speaker: Gray
sp.p: And mine.

sp.speaker: Cobh.
sp.l: Sir, let me crave,
That you would likewise write your name with theirs,
For confirmation of your masters word,
The king of France.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: That will I noble Lord.

sp.speaker: Cobh.
sp.l: So now this action is well knit together,
And I am for you: where is our meeting, lords?

sp.speaker: Camb.
sp.p: Here if you please, the tenth of July next.

sp.speaker: Cobh.
sp.l: In Kent? agreed: now let us in to supper,
I hope your honours will not away tonight.

sp.speaker: Camb.
sp.l: Yes presently, for I have far to ride,
About soliciting of other friends.

sp.speaker: Scroope
sp.l: And we would not be absent from the court,
Lest thereby grow suspicion in the king.

sp.speaker: Cobh.
sp.p: Yet taste a cup of wine before ye go.

sp.speaker: Camb.
sp.p: Not now my lord, we thank you: so farewell.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: Farewell my noble lords: my noble lords?
My noble villains, base conspirators,
How can they look his Highness in the face,
Whom they so closely study to betray?
But I will not sleep until I make it known.
This head shall not be burdened with such thoughts,
Nor in this heart will I conceal a deed
Of such impiety against my king.
Madam, how now?

sp.speaker: Lady cobh.
sp.l: You are welcome home, my Lord,
Why seem ye so disquiet in your looks?
What hath befallen you that disquiets your mind?

sp.p: Bad news I am afraid touching my husband.

sp.speaker: Cobh.
sp.l: Madam, not so: there is your husbands pardon,
Long may ye live, each joy unto the other.

sp.speaker: Powesse
sp.p: So great a kindness as I know not how to make reply, my sense is quite confounded.

sp.speaker: Cobh.
sp.l: Let that alone: and madam stay me not,
For I must back unto the court again
With all the speed I can: Harpoole, my horse.

sp.speaker: Lady Cob.
sp.p: So soon my Lord? what will you ride all night?

sp.speaker: Cobham
sp.l: All night or day it must be so, sweet wife,
Urge me not why or what my business is,
But get you in: Lord Powesse, bear with me,
And madam, think your welcome never the worse:
My house is at your use. Harpoole, away.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Shall I attend your lordship to the court?

sp.speaker: Cobh.
sp.p: Yea sir, your gelding, mount you presently

sp.speaker: Lady Cobh.
sp.l: I prithee Harpoole, look unto thy Lord,
I do not like this sudden posting back.
Some earnest business is a foot belike,
What ever it be, pray God be his good guide.

sp.speaker: Lady Po.
sp.p: Amen that hath so highly us bested.

sp.speaker: Lady Co.
sp.l: Come madam, and my lord, we will hope the best,
You shall not into Wales till he return.

sp.speaker: Powesse
sp.p: Though great occasion be we should depart, yet madam will we stay to be resolved, of this unlooked for doubtful accident.

div.stage: Enter Murley and his men, prepared in some filthy order for warre.

sp.speaker: Murly.
sp.p: Come my hearts of flint, modestly, decently, soberly, and handsomely, no man afore his Leader, follow your master, your Captain, your Knight that shall be, for the honour of Mealmen, Millers, and Malt-men dun is the mouse, Dicke and Tom for the credit of Dunstable, ding down the enemy tomorrow, ye shall not come into the field like beggars, where be Leonard and Laurence my two loaders, Lord have mercy upon us, what a world is this? I would give a couple of shillings for a dozen of good feathers for ye, and forty pence for as many scarfs to set ye out withal, frost and snow, a man has no heart to fight till he be brave.

sp.speaker: Dicke
sp.p: Master I hope we be no babes, for our manhood, our bucklers, and our town footballs can bear witness: and this lite apparel we have shall off, and we will fight naked afore we run away.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p:
Nay, I am of Laurence mind for that, for he means
to leave his life behind him, he and Leonard your two loaders are making their wills because they have wives, now we Bachelors bid our friends scramble for our goods if we die: but master, pray ye let me ride upon Cutte.

sp.speaker: Murly
sp.p: Meal and salt, wheat and malt, fire and tow, frost and snow, why Tom thou shalt: let me see, here are you, William and George are with my cart, and Robin and Hodge holding my own two horses, proper men, handsome men, tall men, true men.

sp.speaker: Dicke
sp.p: But master, master, methinks you are a mad man, to hazard your own person and a cart load of money too.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Yea, and master there is a worse matter in it, if it be as I heard say, we go to fight against all the learned Bishops, that should give us their blessing, and if they curse us, we shall speed never the better.

sp.speaker: Dicke
sp.p: Nay by our lady, some say the King takes their part, and master, dare you fight against the King?

sp.speaker: Murly
sp.p: Fie paltry, paltry in and out, to and fro upon occasion, if the King be so unwise to come there, we will fight with him too.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: What if we should kill the King?

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p: Then we will make another.

sp.speaker: Dicke
sp.p: Is that all, do ye not speak treason?

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p: If we do, who dare trip us? we come to fight for our conscience, and for honour, little know you what is in my bosom, look here mad knaves, a pair of guilt spurs.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: A pair of golden spurs? why do you not put them on your heels? your bosom is no place for spurs.

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p: Be it more or less upon occasion, Lord have mercy us, Tom thou art a fool, and thou speakest treason to knighthood, dare any wear golden or silver spurs till he be a knight? no, I shall be knighted tomorrow, and then they shall on: sirs, was it ever read in the church book of Dunstable, that ever malt man was made knight?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: No but you are more, you are meal-man, malt-man, miller, corn-master and all.

sp.speaker: Dicke
sp.p: Yea, and half a brewer too, and the devil and all for wealth, you bring more money with you, than all the rest.

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p: The more is my honour, I shall be a knight tomorrow, let me spose my men, Tom upon cutte, Dicke upon hobbe, Hodge upon Ball, Raph upon Sorell, and Robin upon the forehorse.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Stand, who comes there?

sp.speaker: Act.
sp.p: All friends, good fellow.

sp.speaker: Murl.
sp.p: Friends and fellows indeed sir Roger.

sp.speaker: Act.
sp.l: Why thus you show yourself a Gentleman,
To keep your day, and come so well prepared,
Your cart stands yonder, guarded by your men,
Who tell me it is laden well with come,
What sum is there?

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p: Ten thousand pound sir Roger, and modestly, decently, soberly, and handsomely, see what I have here against I be knighted.

sp.speaker: Act.
sp.p: Gilt spurs? it is well.

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p: But where is our army sir?

sp.speaker: Act.
sp.l: Dispersed in sundry villages about,
Some here with us in Hygate, some at Finchley,
Totnam, Enfield, Edmunton, Newington,
Islington, Hogsdon, Pancredge, Kenzington,
Some nearer Thames, Ratcliffe, Blackwall and Bow,
But our chief strength must be the Londoners,
Which ere the Sun tomorrow shine,
Will be near fifty thousand in the field.

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p: Mary God dild ye dainty my dear, but upon occasion sir Roger Acton, doth not the King know of it, and gather his power against us.

sp.speaker: Act.
sp.p: No, he is secure at Eltham.

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p: What do the Clergy?

sp.speaker: Act.
sp.p: Fear extremely, yet prepare no force.

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p:
In and out, to and fro, Bully my boykin, we shall
carry the world afore us, I vow by my worship, when I am knighted, we will take the King napping, if he stand on their part.

sp.speaker: Act.
sp.l: This night we few in Higate will repose,
With the first cock we will rise and arm ourselves,
To be in Ficket field by break of day,
And there expect our General.

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p: Sir Iohn Old-castle, what if he come not?

sp.speaker: Bourne
sp.l: Yet our action stands,
Sir Roger Acton may supply his place.

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p: True M. Bourne but who shall make me knight?

sp.speaker: Beuer.
sp.p: He that hath power to be our General.

sp.speaker: Act.
sp.l: Talk not of trifles, come let us away,
Our friends of London long till it be day.

stage.hi: Enter sir Iohn of Wrotham and Doll.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: By my troth, thou art as jealous a man as lives.

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.p: Canst thou blame me Doll, thou art my lands, my goods, my jewels, my wealth, my purse, none walks within forty miles of London, but a plies thee as truly, as the parish does the poor man's box.

sp.speaker: Doll
sp.p: I am as true to thee, as the stone is in the wall, and thou knowest well enough sir Iohn, I was in as good doing, when I came to thee, as any wench need to be: and therefore thou hast tried me, that thou hast: by Gods body, I will not be kept as I have been, that I will not.

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.p: Doll, if this blade hold, there is not a peddler walks with a pack, but thou shalt as boldly choose of his wares, as with thy ready money in a Merchants shop, we will have as good silver as the King coins any.

sp.speaker: Doll
sp.p: What is all the gold spent you took the last day from the Courtier?

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.p: It is gone Doll, it is flown, merely come, merely gone, he comes a horse back that must pay for all, we will have as good meat, as money can get, and as good gowns, as can be bought for gold, be merry wench, the malt-man comes on monday.

sp.speaker: Doll
sp.p: You might have left me at Cobham, until you had been better provided for.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: No sweet Dol, no, I do not like that, yond old ruffian is not for the priest, I do not like a new clerk should come in the old belfry.

sp.speaker: Doll
sp.p: Ah thou art a mad priest in faith.

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.p: Come Doll, I will see thee safe at some alehouse here at Cray, and the next sheep that comes shall leave his fleece.

div.stage: Enter the King, Suffolke and Butler.

sp.speaker: King in great haste.
sp.l: My lord of Suffolk, post away for life,
And let our forces of such horse and foot,
As can be gathered up by any means,
Make speedy rendevous in Tuttle fields,
It must be done this evening my Lord,
This night the rebels mean to draw to head
Near Islington, which if your speed prevent not,
If once they should unite their several forces,
Their power is almost thought invincible,
Away my Lord I will be with you soon.

sp.speaker: Suf.
sp.p: I go my Sovereign with all happy speed.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Make haste my lord of Suffolke as you love us,
Butler, post you to London with all speed.
Command the Mayor, and Sherrifs, on their allegiance,
The city gates be presently shut up,
And guarded with a strong sufficient watch,
And not a man be suffered to pass,
Without a special warrant from ourself.
Command the Postern by the Tower be kept,
And proclamation on the pain of death,
That not a citizen stir from his doors,
Except such as the Mayor and Sherrifs shall choose,
For their own guard, and safety of their persons,
Butler away, have care unto my charge.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: I go my Sovereign.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Butler.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: My Lord.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Go down by Greenewich, and command a boat,
At the Friars bridge attend my coming down.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: I will my Lord.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: It is time I think to look unto rebellion,
When Acton doth expect unto his aid,
No less than fifty thousand Londoners,
Well, I will to Westminster in this disguise,
To hear what news is stirring in these brawls.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn
sp.p: Stand true-man says a thief?

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Stand thief, says a true man, how if a thief?

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn
sp.p: Stand thief too.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Then thief or true-man I see I must stand, I see how soever the world wags, the trade of thieving yet will never down, what art thou?

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: A good fellow.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: So am I too, I see thou dost know me.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn.
sp.p: If thou be a good fellow, play the good fellows part, deliver thy purse without more ado.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: I have no money.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: I must make you find some before we part, if you have no money you shall have ware, as many sound dry blows as your skin can carry.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Is that the plain truth?

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: Sirrah no more ado, come, come, give me the money you have, dispatch, I cannot stand all day.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Well, if thou wilt needs have it, there it is: just the proverb, one thief robs another, where the devil are all my old thieves, that were wont to keep this walk? Falstaffe the villain is so fat, he cannot get on his horse, but methinks Poines and Peto should be stirring hereabouts.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: How much is there on it of thy word?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: A hundred pound in Angels, on my word,
The time has been I would have done as much
For thee, if thou hadst past this way, as I have now.

sp.speaker: sir. Iohn
sp.p: Sirrah, what art thou, thou seemst a gentleman?

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: I am no less, yet a poor one now, for thou hast all my money.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: From whence camest thou?

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: From the court at Eltham.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: Art thou one of the Kings servants?

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Yes that I am and one of his chamber.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: I am glad thou art no worse, thou mayst the better spare thy money, and thinkst thou thou mightst get a poor thief his pardon if he should have need.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Yes that I can.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: Wilt thou do so much for me, when I shall have occasion?

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Yes faith will I, so it be for no murther.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: Nay, I am a pitiful thief, all the hurt I do a man, I take but his purse, I will kill no man.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Then of my word I will do it.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: Give me thy hand of the same.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: There it is.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: Methinks the King should be good to thieves because he has been a thief himself, though I think now he be turned true-man.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Faith I have heard indeed he has had an ill name that way in his youth, but how canst thou tell he has been a thief?

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: How? because he once robbed me before I fell to the trade myself, when that foul villainous guts, that led him to all that roguery, was in his company there, that Falstaffe.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Well if he did rob thee then, thou art but even with him now I will be sworn: thou knowest not the king now, I think, if thou sawest him?

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: Not I in faith.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: So it should seem.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: Well, if old King Henry had lived, this King that is now, had made thieving the best trade in England.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: Because he was the chief warden of our company, it is pity that ever he should have been a King, he was so brave a thief, but sirrah, wilt remember my pardon if need be?

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Yes faith will I.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: Wilt thou? well then because thou shalt go safe, for thou mayst hap (being so early) be met with again, before thou come to Southwarke, if any man when he should bid thee good morrow, bid thee stand, say thou but sir Iohn, and he will let thee pass.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Is that the word? well then let me alone.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: Nay sirrah, because I think indeed I shall have some occasion to use thee, and as thou comest oft this way, I may light on thee another time not knowing thee, here, I will break this Angel, take thou half of it, this is a token betwixt thee and me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: God have mercy, farewell.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: O my fine golden slaves, here is for thee wench in faith, now Dol, we will revel in our beaver, this is a tithe pig of my vicarage, God have mercy neighbour Shooters hill, you paid your tithe honestly. Well I hear there is a company of rebels up against the King, got together in Ficket field near Holborne, and as it is thought here in Kent, the King will be there tonight in his own person, well I will to the Kings camp, and it shall go hard, but if there be any doings, I will make some good boot amongst them.

div.stage: Enter King Henry, Suffolke, Huntington, and two with lights.

sp.speaker: K. Hen.
sp.l: My Lords of Suffolke and of Huntington,
Who scouts it now? or who stands Sentinels?
What men of worth? what Lords do walk the round?

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.p: May it please your Highness.

sp.speaker: K. Hen.
sp.l: Peace, no more of that,
The King is asleep, wake not his majesty,
With terms nor titles, he is at rest in bed,
Kings do not use to watch themselves, they sleep,
And let rebellion and conspiracy,
Revel and havoc in the common wealth,
Is London looked unto?

sp.speaker: Hunt.
sp.l: It is my Lord,
Your noble Uncle Exceter is there,
Your brother Gloucester and my Lord of Warwicke,
Who with the mayor and the Aldermen,
Do guard the gates, and keep good rule within,
The Earl of Cambridge, and sir Thomas Gray,
Do walk the Round, Lord Scroope and Butler skout,
So though it please your majesty to jest,
Were you in bed, well might you take your rest,

sp.speaker: K. Hen.
sp.l: I thank ye Lords, but you do know of old,
That I have been a perfect night-walker,
London you say is safely looked unto,
Alas poor rebels, there your aid must fail,
And the Lord Cobham sir Iohn Old-castle,
He is quiet in Kent, Acton ye are deceived,
Reckon again, you count without your host,
Tomorrow you shall give account to us,
Till when my friends, this long cold winters night,
How can we spend? King Harry is a sleep,
And all his Lords, these garments tell us so,
All friends at football, fellows all in field,
Harry, and Dicke, and George, bring us a drum,
Give us square dice, we will keep this court of guard,
For all good fellows companies that come.
Wheres that mad priest ye told me was in Arms,
To fight, as well as pray, if need required?

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.l: He is in the Camp, and if he knew of this,
I undertake he would not be long hence.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Trip Dicke, Trip George.

sp.speaker: Hunt.
sp.l: I must have the dice,
What do we play at?

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.p: Passage if ye please.

sp.speaker: Hunt.
sp.p: Set round then, so, at all.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: George, you are out.
Give me the dice, I pass for twenty pound,
Here is to our lucky passage into France.

sp.speaker: Hunt.
sp.p: Harry you pass indeed for you sweep all.

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.p: A sign king Harry shall sweep all in France.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: Edge ye good fellows, take a fresh gamester in.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Master Parson? we play nothing but gold?

sp.speaker: sir Iohn.
sp.p: And fellow, I tell thee that the priest hath gold, gold? 'sblood ye are but beggarly soldiers to me, I think I have more gold than all you three.

sp.speaker: Hunt.
sp.p: It may be so, but we believe it not.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Set priest set, I pass for all that gold.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: Ye pass indeed.

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Priest, hast thou any more?

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.l: Zounds what a question is that?
I tell thee I have more than all you three,
At these ten Angels.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.l: I wonder how thou comest by all this gold,
How many benefices hast thou priest?

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: in faith but one, dost wonder how I come by gold? I wonder rather how poor soldiers should have gold, for I will tell thee good fellow, we have every day tithes, offerings, christenings, weddings, burials: and you poor snakes come seldom to a booty. I will speak a proud word, I have but one parsonage, Wrootham, it is better than the Bishopric of Rochester, there is never a hill, heath, nor down in all Kent, but it is in my parish, Barrham down, Chobham down, Gads hill, Wrootham hill, Black heath, Cocks heath, Birchen wood, all pay me tithe, gold quoth he? ye pass not for that.

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.p: Harry ye are out, now parson shake the dice.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn.
sp.p: Set, set I will cover ye at all: A plague on it I am out, the devil, and dice, and a wench, who will trust them?

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.p: Sayst thou so priest? set fair, at all for once.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Out sir, pay all.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.l: 'sblood pay me angel gold,
I will none of your cracked French crowns nor pistolets,
Pay me fair angel gold, as I pay you.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No cracked french crowns? I hope to see more cracked french crowns ere long.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: Thou meanest of French men's crowns, when the King is in France.

sp.speaker: Hunt.
sp.p: Set round, at all.

sp.speaker: sir Ihon
sp.p: Pay all: this is some luck.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Give me the dice, it is I must shred the priest:
At all sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: The devil and all is yours: at that: 'sdeath, what casting is this?

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.p: Well thrown Harry in faith.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I will cast better yet.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: Then I will be hanged. Sirrah, hast thou not given thy soul to the devil for casting?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I pass for all.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.l: Thou passest all that ere I played withal:
Sirrah, dost thou not cog, nor foist, nor slur?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Set parson, set, the dice die in my hand:
When parson, when? what can ye find no more?
Already dry? was it you bragged of your store?

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: All is gone but that.

sp.speaker: Hunt.
sp.p: What, half a broken angel?

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: Why sir, it is gold.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Yea, and I will cover it.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: The devil do ye good on it, I am blind, ye have blown me up.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Nay tarry priest, ye shall not leave us yet,
Do not these pieces fit each other well?

sp.speaker: sir Ihon
sp.p: What if they do?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Thereby begins a tale:
There was a thief, in face much like sir Iohn,
But it was not he, that thief was all in green,
Met me last day on Black Heath, near the park,
With him a woman, I was all alone,
And weaponless, my boy had all my tools,
And was before providing me a boat:
Short tale to make, sir Iohn, the thief I mean,
Took a just hundredth pound in gold from me.
I stormed at it, and swore to be revenged
If ere we met, he like a lusty Thief,
Brake with his teeth this Angel just in two,
To be a token at our meeting next,
Provided, I should charge no Officer
To apprehend him, but at weapons point
Recover that, and what he had beside.
Well met sir Iohn, betake ye to your tools
By torch light, for master parson you are he
That had my gold.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
